review_title: Good research, the rest leaves much to be desired
pros: The science is solid. The people in my immediate teams have always been great, and so have the technical support staff generally. The actual work has always been fantastic to do. Was given significant freedoms to pursue my own ideas in my own time.
cons:
Where do we start? This is specifically about the school of medicine, but many of them are true about the wider university. 

There is no management. There are academics who play at being managers. Favouritism is rife (holding positions for the certain people even if they're not qualified, offering certain support only to certain people). Unchecked bullying, sexism and unaddressed poor management are also rife. 

The administrative support staff are terrible. Any minor thing will take weeks if you don't end up doing it yourself anyway. HR is a hindrance rather than a help, just there to justify their own job rather than do it. Finance are incompetent and you will have to do most of it yourself. Grant support services are very hit and miss, I've had both good and bad experiences there, depending on who you deal with. 

Senior management couldn't care less about research. Undergraduate student satisfaction is the only thing that matters, and research always plays second fiddle. 

The labs are either old and outright hazardous (asbestos everywhere, overheating in winter and boiling in summer, dust actively being blown out of vents giving people asthma attacks) or new and shoddy (bad wiring, bad plumbing). 

Inter-school cooperation is usually a minefield, with private fiefdoms defended to the hilt and no flexibility (I'm looking at you psych.....)

cons: Poor mental health support Great pressure

pros:
The Centre for Trials Research Senior Management team are not just great at performing their individual  job roles but are really great people managers too. They really push staff to develop and show appreciation for work done at all levels. Their motto is "We only succeed if we all succeed".

Equality, Diversity and Inclusion is more than just tick box exercise directed at a University level. It is approached with the same  passion as any clinical trial or project with initiatives to continually improve both recruitment and inclusion within the CTR. 

As others have stated great flexible working, pension, work life balance, holidays. The well-being activities such as bake-off, running club, knit and natter and even wine club are a nice addition to the contractual benefits.
cons: The only con I can think of would be dependent on the type of person you are. Trials and projects start and end frequently so the work you carry out will change quite a bit. A flexible approach is required but if you're the type of person that can show initiative, work autonomously and likes to learn new things this place will accelerate your skill base and allow for progression. There are multiple deadlines based on funding applications, trial initiations and closures, the academic year as well as the financial year so it is a demanding role. Personally I don't think that's a bad thing though and has allowed me to learn an incredible amount in 18 months.

pros: very practically. fit for career aspirations
cons: not really much to say

pros:
Pleasant people to work with.
Potential for flexibility.
Good benefits, terms and conditions and remuneration.
cons:
I've been surprised at the lack of skilled organisation within the University; projects that don't deliver are not held to account, and staff are allowed to do what they like. Academic staff are particularly proud of their lack of accountability and I have witnessed numerous openly stating that they can do as they please without consequence. The converse is true for support staff who are not in receipt of the same flexibility with working conditions and similar; with many staff across all disciplines recognising this inequality and providing a shrug and "what can you do though" response when it's discussed.  Recently it was noted that in half term many of the academic staff bring their kids in to work to save on childcare costs, the support staff are not afforded this same right.

This all adds up to an organisation rife with inequalities and a bullying culture where academic staff are viewed as more important than other staff. And where projects are not delivered; therefore wasting funding and public money.

I've been astonished and disappointed. I am seeking work elsewhere and would not return here for any reason.

pros: Good pension scheme, good annual leave allowance, easy to travel to, just working within a Section expands your knowledge and interests in a variety of subjects, so a little bit of free learning, each day.  Training and personal career development available if agreed with line manager.
cons: Do not follow employment law in respect of things like redundancy and willing make a post redundant then bring in Agency staff because the work must go on.  They do not redeploy staff, staff have to apply for vacant posts and go through the interview and skills asssessment process, they are willing to employ external staff and train them but will not retrain staff being made redundant.  Policies are not adhered to and Schools are able to do what they want.

pros: Student orientated, there are numerous sport facilities, exam facilities are user friendly, Student Support offices always available for students in need.
cons: The procedures for applying to MSc and PhD programs are not always clear and easy to understand. The grants released for the different projects by the research councils are not automatically flagged to the University so sometimes as a student I had to rush on the very last day available to apply for the study project to make sure the in the application there would be enough information to trace the source of the money that would pay the fees.

review_title: Cardiff University need to look after their staff and promote excellence and reward their employees.
pros: Good annual leave entitlement and excellent salary.
cons: Lack of development experience and shadowing opportunities

review_title: There are better places to work in, but not a lot.
pros: Great job flexibility and training are the strongest points. You can leave at pretty much any time and stay as long as you want provided the job is done, although this may depend a lot on your supervisor. You have also strong trainign opportunities with many courses running and there is a Lifelong Learning Centre related to the university for more serious stuff.
cons: The promotions of internal staff are not really promoted and some people is not really helpful. The IT service is particularly bad. the network can be down any time and you receive loads of spam. States also takes ages to sort anything out, so youd better have some basic tools at hand.

review_title: Good work/life balance, but may turn into a dead end.
pros: By far the best thing of working at Cardiff University is the Work/Life balance. In my job I have utter felxibility and self-responsability is assumed since the first day, which is a good thing if you have it.  The university is also placing a good amount of effort to attract the best candidates offering astonishing annual leaves and salaries conmensurate with the top British Universities, even thoug Cardiff is still a cheap place to live in. I would also like to highlight the commitment the make to career development and the sucess of several groups in competing for funds.
cons: Isolation, horrid IT service. Services scattered thougout the city.

review_title: Poor employer not interested in developing staff
pros:
Generally the work life balance is very flexible. Some departments are awful such as Campus Facilities, the individual schools are however far better.
The University pension scheme is very good, even though it is moving away from being finally salary. It compares very well against other employers.
cons:
Uninterested in developing their staff. A big song and dance is made about developing their staff however when it comes down to it there is no money, time or incentive. They are however quick to send you on vacuous and useless in house courses.  
The HR department is next to useless, losing staffs paperwork for new contracts resulting in new starters often not getting paid.
The remuneration is quite poor if you not an academic. 
People who have a job here and climbed a bit are usually content with their lot and stubbornly resist change, new ideas and new ways of working are discouraged.

pros:
Highly rated in the UK and worldwide
Plenty of opportunity for networking
Forward-looking and ready to support projects it deems worthwhile
cons:
As elsewhere, I feel in some cases that more emphasis is placed upon staff members' commercial worth than on their academic contribution.
In certain departments, your administrative duties will leave you with so little time to pursue your research (and, indeed, your teaching duties) that you may be left feeling demoralised, frustrated and exhausted after a few years of service.

review_title: Appalling pockets of inflexibility, lack of modernisation and increasingly low staff morale.
pros:
Mostly nice colleagues (although poor management).
Wonderful students you can support in their time at university.
Lots of holiday!
cons:
Rogue departments not adhering to wider university policies. Central HR not enforcing it even when raised.
Management and HR do not listen or action concerns that are raised.
Many managers are incompetent and out of their depth, unable to modernise their mindset.
No flexibility to working arrangements!!
Likely to get stuck in a grade with no support to progress. 
Losing good staff due to poor management.
Huge amount of unhappiness in remaining staff.

job_title: Student Warden\Conference Assistant in Cardiff, Wales
pros:
- working as a student warden, i got to engage with lots of new people
- During the course of the year i was provided with free accomodation and meals, this helped offset my costs
- Several residences placed across the city, warden application allowed you to select a preference, i was able to get accomodation very close to my school, very convienient for making lectures etc
cons:
- Required high level of organisation to juggle performing warden duties as well as engaging in university pursuits ( both academic and other).
- Prospective cover was expected, so sometimes my plans had to change rapidly

pros: Good annual leave entitlement, fairly secure position, little amount of stress. You can leave work behind when you leave work for the day. Local work place.
cons: Old fashioned working environment. Very bureaucratic and red tape surrounds everything. Hierarchical and very slow to change or develop. Employer isn't interest in staff development unless it benefits the employer. No way for front line staff to make suggestions or communicate with managers or senior managers. Not engaging work at all and needs to improve. Students will eventually realise how much of their loan is being wasted through poor working practices.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Cardiff, Wales
pros: I got my PhD at Cardiff university and went on to become a post doc there for a total of one and a half years. I felt supported by the university throughout both my PhD and post docs.
cons: There could be some improvement in sharing  equipment between Schools/Departments to advance everyone's research. Also, I would prefer if it was possible for post docs to move up the academic ladder within the university, but there doesn't seem to be guidance or enthusiasm for this.

pros: Excellent colleagues. Very nice city. Close to Bristol airport. Two hours away from London. Friendly atmosphere. Cheap city. Affordable houses.
cons: Chaotic management. Last minute scheduling. Unclear promotion process. Heavy bureaucracy. Increased reliance on managerial newspeak. Some students can be arrogant or unreasonably demanding. Little flexibility to organise excellent teaching that is centred on students' needs in spite of the usual rhetorics of excellence. Heavy reliance on part-time, temporary University Teachers.

pros: Very flexible role, choosing the days to work around university study. Friendly working environment where you can meet lots of new people across the university.
cons: Poorly organised at times and little is done to address concerns until the last minute. Rota is inconsistent and seen by some as favouritism, especially when overstaffed during quiet times.

pros: Research hours are regularly flexible, Cardiff University facilities are very good and are open to staff and students, lost cost of living/high quality of life in Cardiff.
cons: Researcher experience can vary greatly between different groups, regularly management is poor as there are many academics with little to no management aptitude and very few managers, communication between departments (eg. academic departments and finance or estates) is poor.

pros: Worked as a RA while an undergraduate. Pay was better than what I could get at Starbucks et al. Worked closely with one of the lecturers who was very approachable.
cons: Work could be mind-numbingly tedius for long periods, and then suddenly be intensely intellectual, then back to tedium. That's pretty standard for RA positions though.

pros: Interesting and innovative work being carried out by people who are at the forefront of their field of research.  Friendly people makes a pleasant working environment.
cons: There is not much structure to the PhD, it does not feel like I am progressing my career, maybe it is because I am not suited to working in research!

pros:
The people - I just can't get over how lovely, driven and hardworking everyone is. A true team atmosphere. 
The work - Varied enough to be interesting at all times.
Location - Many offices around the city centre.
Holiday entitlement - Excellent.
Great pension Contributions.
cons: None as of yet. I would stay forever if I could.

pros:
Good location close to public transport links and the city centre
Excellent Holiday allowance 35 days for FT staff
Felt that life balance was valued
cons:
Stuck in the past
Very difficult to get any change to happen
Technology incredibly outdated
Silo mentality between departments so effort wasted across the whole

pros: As a student, working part-time with the University allows for great working flexibility to fit around your studies and at a great living wage.
cons: As a student intern, my influence sometimes could be slowed down due to the broad University hierarchy but that simply motivated myself to work harder and make myself more noticed!

pros:
Academic freedom
Generally friendly atmosphere
Affordable living in Cardiff
cons: Russell Group university, but doesn't really feel like it. Lots of teaching, admin, supervision, tutoring etc, research comes further down the priority list. CU is run like a business, effort goes into more international students (because £££). Pressure to take on additional roles. CU was deficient, aims to cut staff costs and at the same time do better in teaching, research and admin.

review_title: Fantastic opportunities as a Student Ambassador
pros:
Chance to experience marketing and events promotion first hand
Opportunities to engage with prospective students and get involved in public speaking
Great staff environment with the opportunity to meet other students too
Great remuneration and pay, with good work opportunities including travelling to schools and conferences
cons: Infrequent shifts and events throughout the year

pros: Highly recommend for new graduates or job changers. GOod work/life balance, excellent pay structure, staff benefits good and holiday entitlement generous.
cons: Career Progression often limited unless you are willing to move departments.When change comes it comes fast and with fury throughout the whole organisation - so the ability to cope with change is needed.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Cardiff, Wales
pros: Good city, good university. Nice atmosphere at work. Good quality of research. Cardiff is a nice city with parks and seafront.
cons: Fixed term contract running out in 3 years. No possibility of extending the contract. In a Postdoc it is sometimes hard to motivate yourself.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Cardiff university Queens Buildings, Wales
pros: Great people. Great city. Great location. The courses are extensive and can tailor to the needs of the few.
cons: Bit difficult to commumicate with the university. A lot of red tape to get through in order to get your point across.

pros: Flexibility, you are allowed to work from home on some occasions. Even if you are an entry level staff your opinions are valued. Opportunity to develop other skills provided.
cons: The job can get a bit monotonous at times especially if you have to stick to one project for a year or more.

pros: Stimulating intellectual environment. Good research ethos and opportunities for multi-disciplinary research. High quality academic colleagues and teachers.
cons: Increasing bureaucratisation and process driven decision making. Little room for flexibility and strategic policy making

pros:
Lovely facilities and building
Plenty of opportunity to move around within
Really nice people
Flexible
cons:
Just really bored
Moves at a lot slower pace than private companies
Didn't feel challenged enough
Very tight on budgets

review_title: Great colleagues - too much red tape!
pros:
some fantastic, helpful and knowledgeable colleagues
great scientific environment 
good infrastructure and state of the art scientific equipment
substantial academic freedom
very diverse  students - often great fun too
cons: Much too much red tape - you name - it we've got a form...

review_title: The job is busy and I like dealing with the students.
job_title: UG and Assessment Assistant in Cardiff, Wales
pros: They have good family friendly policies and annual leave.  The lower grades are also good for starting positions after University.
cons: They can expect a lot for your grade and it’s also hard to get some higher grades without a degree.

review_title: Great Benefits, not always the best conditions
pros: Higher than average holiday days, good pay and generally flexible working hours
cons: Can sometimes be very rigid to sticking to set roles, and has a habit of forcing through relatively unnecessary wholesale restructure projects.

review_title: an average PhD student in Cardiff University
pros: Nice town. Quiet workplace. Generally with helpful staff
cons: Old buiding. Too much administration. Not enough scientific staff. Tend to burden few with a lot of teaching and training duty, even if it is not their job (phd students and technicians instead of post-docs)

pros: The University is growing a lot and there are a lot of investments and opportunities in specific areas. The pension plan is very good.
cons: Specific working conditions will depend on the School and the supervisor, so it is hard to share a useful review.

review_title: Bureaucratic but otherwise very well organised
pros: Good support. provides good work material. Good work environment, amicable atmosphere.
cons: The stipend is minimal but manageable. A bureaucracy, I have to spend a lot of time filling in forms, writing reports and making presentations which can be very distracting

pros: Friendly place to work, people are lovely.  Pay is above average, min 32 days leave per year.
cons: Where I worked there was no flexi working, although I was able to change my hours.  It can be stressful at times.

pros:
If you like research you might like it.
Freedom to pursue what you are interested in.
Own time management.
cons: It's research so be successful you'll need to dismiss the very concept of work/life balance.

pros: great leave, central services seem better
cons:
don't work in a school
Run poorly
not organised
Don't hire people unless they are internal

review_title: Little support for long term staff
pros: Flexible working hours, good annual leave entitlement
cons: Heavy reliance on fixed term contracts means little job security and no loyalty to exisiting staff members

review_title: It's one of the best work places
pros: Supportive and genuine team member, reasonable workload, line managers being very generous of supporting our long term career developments
cons: I hope I could stay much longer and I am currently seeking for new opportunities

pros: Good working environment with balanced work ethos, friendly work colleagues, great place to work I can completely recommend.
cons: Busy, must be totally committed to the post - but I loved it.

review_title: Seeking a PhD in Cardiff University?
pros: Good opportunity for growth in research profile at a good standing University
cons: Salary is ok if you live in Wales. Maybe a bit tight if you live in England and need to commute

pros: big emplyer where everybody is threated with respect
cons: Research Associates work on fixed term contract and are expected to go when the project ends. This help keep the cost employers low.

pros: Very generous holiday allowance of 32 days.
cons: I work within Professional Services and find that there are quite poor development opportunities available within the University. Nothing is really invested in staff development. More senior managers show little interest in front line staff.

pros: Cardiff university always looks at redeployment before redundancies are made., and offer a good pension package
cons: Does not communicate  well at all times and fails to let staff know what the university is achieving.

pros:
- great atmosphere 
- good social network and life
- great pay 
- can work when you want
cons: - sometimes pressured to do club shifts if you don't want them

review_title: Very good research and teaching institution!
pros: Good professional development courses. Good working environment.  People are really helpful.
cons: Everything is good here! As a research university, all the facilities are really good.

pros: Pay was great! Staff were great and plenty of opportunities to grow and do more
cons: Can't think of any, may not enough time to work for them

pros: Really good with hours, your own availability can be set. Pays above minimum wage. Friendly environment.
cons: Night club shifts can sometimes leave you finishing work at 4.30am.

pros: The work involves lot of communication and involvement
cons: Sometimes little stressful during busy times but that the nature of the job

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Cardiff, Wales
pros: Pay their Postdoc's well in a city which is very affordable to live in.
cons: Needs more support to keep talented young PIs.

pros: Pay, Pension and Annual Leave is all good. Great opportunities for development
cons: Things are always changing. It's important that you can keep up with the changes

pros:
Lots of annual leave
Great flexibility
cons:
Contract based work
Low Salary
Don't expect 100% time for research
Lots of additional duties e.g. supervision of students, teaching, supporting seminars,

pros: Good research environment. Great colleagues. Positive and supportive culture.
cons: Expectations of staff very high, however I'd imagine this is no different from any other UKHE institution at present.

pros: holiday, resaonable pay and I worked with a nice set of people
cons: managers, restructure every few years

pros: I was a student for several years and enjoyed my time there, very supportive, good quality organisation.
cons: I found the work very hard, particularly the final year.

pros: Friendly, encouraging, interesting and social, the best time!
cons: Sad that its over but excited for the doors it has enabled me to open for my future!

review_title: Great opportunity for research with plenty of support
pros:
- High impact research
- Surrounded by talented colleagues
cons: - Progression can be limited by current funding availability

pros: The School of Chemistry is really nice and I learned a lot there.
cons: There were not much space, some space had to be shared.

pros: A peaceful city with nice people here. Love working here.
cons: The cafeteria is not satisfying and food is not healthy.

pros: Very rewarding job working with a variety of students with disabilities
cons: Hours are flexible, but cannot be relied upon for full time work

review_title: Poor structure a the Engineering Department
pros: Freedom to pursue any research path you like
cons: Great lack of resources to  be able to produce good quality research

pros: staffs are very friendly, a good place to study and work.
cons: the school's building is too big , easily get lost sometimes.

pros: It has a good research environment and very flexible working time. Colleagues are very nice and friendly.
cons: Pay is not very good.

pros: fantastic security and great annual leave
cons: disorganised and lack of planning. poor attitude to flexible working

pros: Good supportive specialty specific team
cons: Executive need to be more organised, management focused and have a greater awareness and support to their subordinates.

review_title: Great for employees, slow to innovate

cons: Slow to innovate and organisation is a very large, complicated beast.

review_title: Computer Science dept. great place to work
pros: Good technical environment for teaching, engagement with business, good benefits

pros: Excellent professional development and support through leadership and peer support.
cons: Some teaching techniques are a little out dated

pros: Easy to work around your university schedule, fairly simple work

pros: The research undertaken is excellence and this carriers through to the classroom experience

pros: high research standards in some areas like neuroscince

pros: Fantastic environment, wonderful and friendly people, creates an atmosphere for innovative work.

pros: A prestigious institution, reasonable pay, inspiring work
